SENT.plain: Because long survival after resection of esophageal carcinoma is uncommon, second esophageal cancers are rare
We report the case of a patient in whom adenocarcinoma developed within residual Barrett's esophagus 19 years after esophagectomy for stage IIb Barrett's adenocarcinoma
Implications relative to the type of operation and adequacy of resection are discussed
Long-term survival after Barrett's adenocarcinoma may occur more often if surveillance protocols achieve their aim
Questions concerning the management of such patients are identified
